trial_identification.studytitle: Does the perioperative use of Gabapentin reduce analgesia requirements in patients having delayed open reduction and internal fixation of forearm or ankle fractures?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Do patients who are having delayed open reduction and internal fixation of forearm or ankle fractures and who are given gabapentin peri-operatively, when compared with patients not given gabapentin, show lower narcotic analgesic requirements

interventions.interventions: Pre-operative and post-operative treatment with gabapentin for 24 hours. Preoperative dose would normally be 600 mg orally 30 minutes prior to surgery with 300 mg being given orally 8 hourly for 24 hours following completion of surgery. The doses would need to be reduced if a patient with moderate or worse renal failure was recruited.
interventions.comparator: Placebo - indistinguishable gelatin capsule filled with starch

primaryOutcome.outcome: Total dose of fentanyl used over period of study - intra-operatively and via Patient Controlled Analgesia (PCA) device
primaryOutcome.timepoint: After 24 hours use of PCA, started immediately after surgery.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At any time following the administration of the initial dose of gabapentin until up to 24 hours of subsequent gabapentin use.
At any time following the administration of the initial dose of gabapentin until up to 24 hours of subsequent gabapentin use.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Sedation (using a score combining sedation (0-2) and rousability(Yes/No))
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At any time following the administration of the initial dose of gabapentin until up to 24 hours of subsequent gabapentin use.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Have to have a fracture of the wrist or ankle that is to be treated by internal fixation and be able to understand how to use a PCA device.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pregnancy, Non-adult patients due to the hospital being non-paediatric, any patient unable to use PCA.

trial_design.concealment: Recruitment would be from patients presented for emergency surgery. This is of relatively low urgency and would allow adequate time for reflection after the subjects were approached. If recruitment was succesful then allocation is concealed by the use of central randomisation.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Gabapentin is a drug that is officially used to treat chronic pain. This study looks at whether it can help with the more acute pain from having broken bones in the wrist or ankle repaired with screws and plates. This is very painful for a relatively short period and if we find that gabapentin can help with this pain then this could become part of normal treatment.
